items.title: Passing a string of an expanded user (Pathlib) into observer.schedule gives Illegal Instruction 4
items.body:
As per the title, the commented out code works, while using Pathlib gives me an Illegal Instruction 4. Printing the paths to terminal shows they're set correctly, and commenting out the observer.schedule line runs the program with no errors.

```
class ObserverLoop:
    def __init__(self):
        self.folder = Path("~/Desktop")
        print(self.folder.expanduser())
        # self.working_path = os.path.abspath(os.path.expanduser("~/" + "/Desktop/"))
        self.working_path = self.folder.expanduser()
        print(self.working_path)
        self.event_handler = MonitorFolderChanges(self.working_path)

    def start_loop(self):
        tf.key = secrets.api_key
        observer = Observer()

        observer.schedule(self.event_handler, self.working_path, recursive=False)
        observer.start()

        try:
            while observer.is_alive():
                observer.join(1)
        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            observer.stop()

        observer.join()
```

items.title: Recursive inotify monitoring fails on inaccessible directories
items.body:
Using version 0.10.2:
```
$ watchmedo log --recursive /path
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".local/bin/watchmedo", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/watchmedo.py", line 576, in main
    parser.dispatch()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/argh/helpers.py", line 55, in dispatch
    return dispatch(self, *args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/argh/dispatching.py", line 174, in dispatch
    for line in lines:
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/argh/dispatching.py", line 277, in _execute_command
    for line in result:
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/argh/dispatching.py", line 231, in _call
    result = function(namespace_obj)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/watchmedo.py", line 350, in log
    observe_with(observer, handler, args.directories, args.recursive)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/watchmedo.py", line 116, in observe_with
    observer.start()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/api.py", line 253, in start
    emitter.start()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/utils/__init__.py", line 110, in start
    self.on_thread_start()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify.py", line 121, in on_thread_start
    self._inotify = InotifyBuffer(path, self.watch.is_recursive)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_buffer.py", line 35, in __init__
    self._inotify = Inotify(path, recursive)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 200, in __init__
    self._add_dir_watch(path, recursive, event_mask)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 395, in _add_dir_watch
    self._add_watch(full_path, mask)
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 409, in _add_watch
    Inotify._raise_error()
  File "/home/user/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 425, in _raise_error
    raise OSError(err, os.strerror(err))
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied
```

There is a directory under /path that the current user does not have read or execute permission for.

The error is raised within watchdog itself so there's no way to ignore this in the event handler. There's no exception raised if an inaccessible directory is created (`umask 0777; mkdir test`) on a path that is already being recursively monitored (although it won't start monitoring inside it if its permissions are later changed).

items.title: Passing `pathlib.Path` to `Observer.schedule()` causes a trap in `Observer.start()` on MacOS
items.body:
(This is not a regression of #26!  :-))

See this minimal example: https://github.com/rec/backer/blob/bpt-trap/bpt_trap.py

On MacOS, it causes a `BPT trap Compilation trace/BPT trap: 5` (something like a SEGV if you are Linux person) on Python 3.6.6, Python 3.7.0, and Python 3.8.1 exactly if `PATH` is a `pathlib.Path`.

The workaround is to cast the `Path` to a `str` before calling `Observer.schedule()`.

items.title: Installation trips an error on non-macOS platforms because of indirect dependency on pyobjc-core
items.body:
Installing this package on non-macOS platforms prints this error:

> An error occurred when reading setup.py or setup.cfg: 'Attribute' object has no attribute 'id'

Which is caused by [this issue](https://bitbucket.org/ronaldoussoren/pyobjc/issues/291/install-fails-on-non-macos-platforms) in pyobjc-core, which watchdog depends on through these paths:

watchdog -> pyobjc-framework-FSEvents -> pyobjc-core
watchdog -> pyobjc-framework-Cocoa -> pyobjc-core

Overall installation still succeeds, unless installing on Windows with `$ErrorActionPreference = "Stop"`.

items.title: v0.10.1 broke Ubuntu 16.04 install via pip
items.body:
I manage a package ([Dactyl](https://github.com/ripple/dactyl/)) that uses watchdog as a dependency. Starting with the release of Watchdog v0.10.1, our Dockerized builds (Ubuntu 16.04) are failing on an `ImportError` for `pathtools` that ultimately comes from watchdog.

After some investigation, it appears to be that `pip3 install watchdog` no longer installs the necessary `pathtools` dependency because pip doesn't look at the `setup.cfg` file. This issue may be masked on some OSes because it's common for pathtools to be installed by default, but I was able to reproduce as follows:

1. Creating a fresh Ubuntu 16.04 install (I did it on a VM)
2. `sudo apt-get install python3-pip`
3. `pip3 install watchdog`
4. `python3`
5. At the Python prompt:

        from watchdog.observers import Observer

    The result is similar to this error:

          File "/home/username/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/watchdog/observers/__init__.py", line 63, in <module>
            from .inotify import InotifyObserver as Observer
          File "/home/username/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify.py", line 83, in <module>
            from watchdog.events import (
          File "/home/username/.local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/watchdog/events.py", line 91, in <module>
            from pathtools.patterns import match_any_paths
        ImportError: No module named 'pathtools'

Manually installing `pathtools` with pip fixes the error.

I suspect the changes in commit 6baa210d605459c8d2c5ddcac146c001cdf2f24d to remove `pathtools` from `install_requires` are the cause.

items.title: FreeBSD kqueue: 'module' object is not callable
items.body:
Latest version (`0.10.1`) of watchdog on FreeBSD fails with:

```
  File ".../python3.7/site-packages/watchdog/observers/kqueue.py", line 439, in custom_stat
    stat_info = stat(path)
TypeError: 'module' object is not callable
```

Downgrading to version 0.9.0 works fine, so I am guessing it has to do with changes introduced here: d092a698e0edc7e3e9075653b982a5636d592e8c

I guess #532 would be awesome to prevent this :-) good to see it's somehow on the radar!

items.title: argh not found
items.body:
In the latest version of watchdog (0.10.0), we have to currently, explicitly install `argh` in order our processes to start. Without `argh` explicitly installed, we see the following exception:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/env/bin/watchmedo", line 6, in <module>
    from watchdog.watchmedo import main
  File "/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/watchdog/watchmedo.py", line 39, in <module>
    from argh import arg, aliases, ArghParser, expects_obj
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'argh'
```

items.title: second install of watchdog on non-macos incorrectly requires darwin dependencies
items.body:
If I run `pip install watchdog` on a clean python environment it works fine and doesn't install the pyobjc dependencies, although pip does output what look like warnings or errors:
```
watchdog 0.10.0 requires pyobjc-framework-Cocoa>=4.2.2, which is not installed.
watchdog 0.10.0 requires pyobjc-framework-FSEvents>=4.2.2, which is not installed.
```
If I run `pip install watchdog` again pip does see it as already installed but then tries to install the pyobjc dependencies and fails. Here's the full command output:

```
watchdog 0.10.0 requires pyobjc-framework-Cocoa>=4.2.2, which is not installed.

You are using pip version 18.0, however version 20.0.2 is available.
You should consider upgrading via the 'pip install --upgrade pip' command.
```

items.title: Can't pickle DirectorySnapshots
items.body:
First of all, I'm not sure if this is an issue, an expected behaviour or just an scenario not aimed to be solved.

## Expected Behavior
I expect to be able to pickle DirectorySnapshot objects, as I can do in the latest release, 0.9.0.

## Current Behavior
I can't pickle a DirectorySnapshot because I'm getting a PicklingError.
It doesn't happen on the 0.9.0 version.

## Possible Solution
One possible workaround is using the `dill` library and it would work, but I find it strange to not make it work with `pickle` like it did before because it breaks existing code.

The following works:
```python
import dill
from src.watchdog.utils.dirsnapshot import DirectorySnapshot

dill.dumps(DirectorySnapshot("/Users/alex/tmp"))
```

## Steps to Reproduce
1. Clone the repository with the latest `master` commit. Currently `7a55f317946953d86a5acea64d9b31931ca25307`.
2. Try to pickle a DirectorySnapshot. Notice the import from `src` directory, not the pypi version.
```python
import pickle
from src.watchdog.utils.dirsnapshot import DirectorySnapshot

pickle.dumps(DirectorySnapshot("/Users/alex/tmp"))
```
3. You will see the following exception:
```python
_pickle.PicklingError: Can't pickle <function DirectorySnapshot.<lambda> at 0x10dfb20d0>: attribute lookup DirectorySnapshot.<lambda> on src.watchdog.utils.dirsnapshot failed
```

## Context (Environment)
I'm facing this problem while using both python 3.7 and python 3.8 in a macOS Mojave 10.14.6.

In my scenario I need to pickle a DirectorySnapshot object to later compare it with the current snapshot and see if there was any change while my program was down.

## Possible Implementation
I just propose to make it work with `pickle`. Maybe the problematic lambda is not required and we can just avoid serializing it using `__getstate__`.

Otherwise it just doesn't have a solution and we have to change to using the `dill` library.

items.title: For large sized files, 'FileCreatedEvent' is not waiting till the file has finished copying
items.body:
For large sized files, 'FileCreatedEvent' is triggered when the file first appears in the directory.
If we try to read that, we will get file corrupted exception as the file is not yet copied completely. 
The workaround what we can do is checking the file size continuously in a loop and once the size is stable, we can continue with the process:
 file_size =  0
 while file_size != os.path.getsize(event.src_path):
     file_size = os.path.getsize(event.src_path)
     time.sleep(1)
I'm not feeling this solution is a perfect one.

items.title: rename/move event on NFS triggers create and delete event
Python process can not delete folder that is being observed
items.body:
If you try to delete a folder that is being observed by a python process using watchdog and then try to delete it using another python process the folder becomes unavailable until the watchdog process stops.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a folder to observe: **C:\\test_folder**
2. Create a python script using watchdog to observe this folder:
```python
import sys
import time
import logging
from watchdog.observers import Observer
from watchdog.events import LoggingEventHandler

if __name__ == "__main__":
    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO,
                        format='%(asctime)s - %(message)s',
                        datefmt='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    path = 'C:\\test_folder'
    event_handler = LoggingEventHandler()
    observer = Observer()
    observer.schedule(event_handler, path, recursive=True)
    observer.start()
    try:
        while True:
            time.sleep(1)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        observer.stop()
    observer.join()
```

3. Open a python shell and try to delete this folder:
```python
import os
for root, dirs, files in os.walk('C:\\test_folder'):
    for f in files:
    os.remove(os.path.join(root, f))
    os.rmdir('C:\\test_folder')
```

4. Check that the **C:\\test_folder** still appear in file explorer and you are not able to open
5. Stop watchdog process
6. Folder has been deleted

items.title: Fix documentation inconsistencies, README, ...
items.body:
Hi,

There are two documentation sites available that I saw online:

- [pythonhosted.org](https://pythonhosted.org/watchdog/) which is crearly outdated as it is on 0.8.2, which you could not notice unless you check PyPI or github and notice that 0.9.0 is the latest release. This is also linked from that [watchdog3](https://pypi.org/project/watchdog3/) fork.
- [readthedocs.org](https://watchdog.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html) introduced in 2013 which does not state any version number and has a 2010 copyright notice. But the title tag says 0.6.0, so also outdated.

So... it appears there's no current documentation build out there.

#410 (2017) proposed to migrate to ReadTheDocs which was actualy done in PR #137 (in 2013!). The issue could be closed as invalid as it is done already. But maybe the README link to documentation should be updated. Or close as wontfix and revert PR #137.

So, regardless of the approach:

- The README should link to the correct documentation build,
- the incorrect one should be taken down to avoid confusion
- documentation shall be updated to the latest release

Last but not least: #565 complains about documentation not stating python 3 support, which could be closed once the above is fixed.

On a side note, I mention this here because the [watchdog3](https://github.com/nuxeo/watchdog3) repository is read-only: a request should be put to Nuxeo to push a new release to PyPI so the package package gets updated with the new README (which states the project is unmaintained), otherwise you get a first impression that watchdog does not support python3.

items.title: Discern end of copy process?
items.body:
On Windows, I need to watch a directory for the appearance of a new item. Now this is straightforward, but the catch here is that the new item will be a directory hierarchy. In other words, someone will copy a new tree into this location. I will not be in a position to know anything about the number of files and directories in the new tree, nor their size (and they could be sizable, up to 100GB). But I don't want to take any action  until AFTER all the files have been copied. 

Is there an elegant way to know for sure when the last part of the tree have finished copying? There are hacky solution where I could watch for the calculated size of the folder to stop growing, but I'm not in love with that approach... I'd like to control the initial copy, since that would give me some leverage, but that's out of the question at the moment....

```
mainDir
    -- dir1
```

items.title: observer.start() segfault on Mac OS X
items.body:
Hello

I have been playing around with `watchdog` and am running into segfaults. Specifically, I receive this output when the `watcher_thread` line is replaced by the commented line:

```
HandleNewFile#start
HandleNewFile#_process
Illegal instruction: 4
```

The error occurs on the `observer.start()` invocation.

```python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-

import os
import queue
import threading
import time

from watchdog import events, observers


def get_runner(file_handler, directory):
    def runner():
        observer = observers.Observer()
        observer.schedule(file_handler, directory, recursive=True)
        observer.start()
    return runner


DEBUG_SEGFAULT = True


class DataWatcher:

    def start(self):
        data_directory = Path('.') / 'data' / 'some_folder'
        if not os.path.exists(data_directory):
            os.makedirs(data_directory)

        file_handler = HandleNewFile()
        file_handler.start()

        if DEBUG_SEGFAULT:
            # segfault
            watcher_thread = threading.Thread(target=get_runner(file_handler, data_directory.absolute()))
        else:
            # no segfault
            watcher_thread = threading.Thread(target=get_runner(file_handler, '.'))

        watcher_thread.start()


class HandleNewFile(events.FileSystemEventHandler):

    def __init__(self, pattern=None):
        self.pattern = pattern or ('.xml', '.tiff', '.jpg', '.json')
        self.event_q = queue.Queue()
        self.dummy_thread = None

    def on_any_event(self, event: events.FileSystemEvent) -> None:
        print(f'HandleNewFile#on_any_event: {event}')
        if not event.is_directory and event.src_path.endswith(self.pattern):
            self.event_q.put((event, time.time()))

    def start(self) -> None:
        print('HandleNewFile#start')
        self.dummy_thread = threading.Thread(target=self._process)
        self.dummy_thread.daemon = True
        self.dummy_thread.start()

    def _process(self) -> None:
        print('HandleNewFile#_process')
        while True:
            time.sleep(1)
```

_Program above was pulled/modified from [this SO post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50593200/flask-application-with-watchdog-observer); I have just been messing around with it._

------------

**Watchdog `0.9.0`**
**Mac OS X `10.13.6`**
**Python `3.7.3`**

_EDIT: Removed some of the noise from the code_

items.title: Support SIGUSR1 and SIGUSR2 in auto-restart --signal
items.body:
`SIGUSR1` and `SIGUSR2` aren't supported because [the regex](https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/blob/master/src/watchdog/watchmedo.py#L534) in watchmedo doesn't match them. 

```python

    if re.match('^SIG[A-Z]+$', args.signal):
        stop_signal = getattr(signal, args.signal)
```

items.title: Set changed size during iteration on macOS
items.body:
I had this errors while using watchdog:
```python
RuntimeError: Set changed size during iteration
  File "nxdrive/engine/workers.py", line 171, in run
    self._execute()
  File "nxdrive/direct_edit.py", line 651, in _execute
    self._setup_watchdog()
  File "nxdrive/engine/activity.py", line 118, in func_wrapper
    func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "nxdrive/direct_edit.py", line 686, in _setup_watchdog
    self._observer.start()
  File "watchdog/observers/api.py", line 251, in start
    for emitter in self._emitters:
```

I am not able to reproduce manually as of now, but a simple fix would be:
```python
for emitter in self.emitters.copy():
```

items.title: macOS: TypeError: PyCObject_AsVoidPtr called with null pointer
items.body:
On macOS this program fails:

```
import time

from os import mkdir, unlink, rmdir
from os.path import join, exists

from watchdog.observers import Observer
from watchdog.events import FileSystemEventHandler

def main(local_path):
    if not exists(local_path):
        mkdir(local_path)
    a = join(local_path, "a")
    mkdir(a)

    o = Observer()
    o.start()
    w = o.schedule(FileSystemEventHandler(), a, recursive=False)

    rmdir(a)
    time.sleep(0.1)

    o.unschedule(w)

main("PyCObject_AsVoidPtr_called_with_null_pointer")
```

with this traceback:

```
$ python err6.py
/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.15_2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/threading.py:1151: RuntimeWarning: tp_compare didn't return -1 or -2 for exception
  return _active[_get_ident()]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "err6.py", line 24, in <module>
    main("PyCObject_AsVoidPtr_called_with_null_pointer")
  File "err6.py", line 22, in main
    o.unschedule(w)
  File "/Users/administrator/Environments/watchdog-it-all/lib/python2.7/site-packages/watchdog/observers/api.py", line 345, in unschedule
    self._remove_emitter(emitter)
  File "/Users/administrator/Environments/watchdog-it-all/lib/python2.7/site-packages/watchdog/observers/api.py", line 225, in _remove_emitter
    emitter.join()
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.15_2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 930, in join
    if self is current_thread():
  File "/usr/local/Cellar/python@2/2.7.15_2/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 1151, in currentThread
    return _active[_get_ident()]
TypeError: PyCObject_AsVoidPtr called with null pointer
```

items.title: Events from non-ASCII paths raise UncodeDecodeError
items.body:
```
from os import mkdir
from watchdog.observers.inotify import InotifyObserver
from watchdog.events import FileSystemEventHandler

class H(FileSystemEventHandler):
    def on_any_event(self, event):
        print(event)

def main():
    d = u"demo"
    handler = H()

    mkdir(d)
    obs = InotifyObserver()
    obs.schedule(handler, d, recursive=True)
    obs.start()
    mkdir(u"/".join((d, u"\N{SNOWMAN}")))
    obs.join()

main()
```

results in this exception

```
Exception in thread Thread-3:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 801, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "watchdog/src/watchdog/observers/inotify_buffer.py", line 87, in run
    inotify_events = self._inotify.read_events()
  File "watchdog/src/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 324, in read_events
    inotify_event = InotifyEvent(wd, mask, cookie, name, src_path)
  File "watchdog/src/watchdog/observers/inotify_c.py", line 478, in __init__
    self._name = name.decode()
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xe2 in position 0: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Apparently introduced in 0c5e3531748d231e34ef6ecf8581ac20fd956b25

items.title: Wrong source path after renaming a top level folder
items.body:
Steps to reproduce in Ubuntu 18.04

Start monitoring a folder in recursive mode p.e. "/"
Create Folder A
**"/A"**
Create Folder B inside A 
**"/A/B"**
Rename A -> A2
**"/A2/B"**
Create a file inside B, named example.txt
**/A2/B/example.txt**

Bug: The src_path of the event fired when creating the file example.txt is
**/A/B/example.txt**
and should be
**/A2/B/example.txt**

items.title: Can I watch files created on NFS using watch dog observer?
items.body:
I created a simple FileSystemEventHandler to watch for new files. However when I specify an NFS share location it doesnt trigger any event. 

Can watchdog observer for file events on NFS? 
```
/remote/nfs/testdir/<file> -  Doesn't work
/SCRATCH/testdir/<file> - Works

```

`#!/usr/bin/env python3
import sys
import time
import logging
# watchdog
from watchdog.observers import Observer
from watchdog.events import FileSystemEventHandler


class Watcher:
    """
    Watch for events
    """

    def __init__(self, path):
        """
        Watch specified path for changes
        """
        self.path = path
        print(path)
        self.observer = Observer()

    def watch(self):
        """
        watch function to watch for events
        """
        print(self.path)
        event_handler = Handler()
        self.observer.schedule(event_handler, self.path, recursive=True)
        self.observer.start()
        try:
            while True:
                print("watching")
                time.sleep(5)
        except BaseException:
            self.observer.stop()
            print("Error")
        self.observer.join()


class Handler(FileSystemEventHandler):

    @staticmethod
    def on_any_event(event):
        print(event)
        if event.is_directory:
            return None
        elif event.event_type == 'created':
            # Take any action here when a file is first created.
            print("Received created event - %s." % event.src_path)
        elif event.event_type == 'modified':
            # Taken any action here when a file is modified.
            print("Received modified event - %s." % event.src_path)



if __name__ == "__main__":
    watcher = Watcher("/SCRATCH/testwatch")
    watcher.watch()`

items.title: `Modified Event` were not triggered when file size has changed of `PollingObserver` or  `PollingObserverVFS`
items.body:
`PollingObserver` works well in most cases.
When `dd` commands were executed on `cephfs`, file size were changed, but `Modified Event` could not be triggered. 
command: ```dd if=/dev/zero of=test count=1 bs=1G```
I looked at the filesystem and found that the modified time of the file would not change during `dd`. This problem is found only when the count parameter of the `dd` command is 1 on `cephfs`.
I recommend add the judgment of file size of `Modified Event`.

items.title: Problem with recursive [following issue #143]
items.body:
``` python
#! /usr/bin/python

import os
import os.path
import sys
import time
import logging
from watchdog.observers import Observer
from watchdog.events import LoggingEventHandler

if __name__ == "__main__":
    logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO,
                        format='%(asctime)s - %(message)s',
                        datefmt='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    path = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else '.'
    event_handler = LoggingEventHandler()
    observer = Observer()
    observer.schedule(event_handler, path, recursive=False)
    observer.start()

    if not os.path.isdir('watchdog_test'):
        os.mkdir('watchdog_test')
    open('watchdog_test/test.txt', 'w').close()

    try:
        while True:
            time.sleep(1)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        observer.stop()
    observer.join()
```

Executing the code above leads to the following output with v.0.6.0 (despite setting 'Recursive' to 'False'):

```
2013-12-11 16:43:05 - Created directory: /.../projects/watchdog/watchdog_test
2013-12-11 16:43:05 - Created file: /.../projects/watchdog/watchdog_test/test.txt
2013-12-11 16:43:05 - Modified file: /.../projects/watchdog/watchdog_test/test.txt
```

And to the following output when using the source version (which leads to correct behaviour):

```
2013-12-12 11:39:59 - Created directory: /.../projects/watchdog/watchdog_test
```

Therefore, the issue seems to be fixed and could be closed.

_Originally posted by @cpriebe in https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/issues/143#issuecomment-30405792_

items.title: Delect directory on win10,but  event.isdirectory = False.
The watchdog with pygame
items.body:
I would like to use the watchdog with pygame, is this possible? The purpose of my script is that when something happens in the folder a video will be displayed. The problem is that when I run the script it does not return any errors.

Here's the code I'm using.

```
#!/usr/bin/python
import time
import os
import pygame
from moviepy.editor import *
from watchdog.observers import Observer
from watchdog.events import FileSystemEventHandler

link = 'abs\\'

def detectFile():    
    pygame.display.set_caption('Hello World!')
    clip = VideoFileClip('01.mp4')
    clip.preview(fps=30,fullscreen=True)
    pygame.quit()


class MyHandler(FileSystemEventHandler):
    def on_modified(self, event):
        print 'test'
        detectFile()        

if __name__ == "__main__":
    event_handler = MyHandler()
    observer = Observer()
    observer.schedule(event_handler, path=link, recursive=False)
    observer.start()

    try:
        while True:
            time.sleep(1)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        observer.stop()
    observer.join()
```

items.title: Can't supress watchdog.observers.inotify_buffer DEBUG logs
items.body:
How do I stop these logs?

```shell
2018-11-12T18:26:08.427858519Z 2018-11-12 18:26:08,427 - watchdog.observers.inotify_buffer - DEBUG - in-event <InotifyEvent: src_path=b'x/y/z/xxxx.tdt', wd=10, mask=IN_MODIFY, cookie=0, name=b'xxxx.tdt'>
```
tried this to no avail

```python
observer = Observer()
observer.schedule(event_handler, input_dir, recursive=True)
observer.start()
logging.getLogger("watchdog.observers.inotify_buffer").setLevel("INFO")
```

```shell
bash-4.4# pip show watchdog
Name: watchdog
Version: 0.9.0
Summary: Filesystem events monitoring
Home-page: http://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog
Author: Yesudeep Mangalapilly
Author-email: yesudeep@gmail.com
License: Apache License 2.0
Location: /usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages
Requires: argh, PyYAML, pathtools
Required-by:
```

items.title: For python 3.7, we should use collections.abc.MutableSet
Release cycle
items.body: @danilobellini what do you think to publish releases more often? For instance there are several bug fixes in the current unreleased version. Perhaps could you publish a 0.9.1 with those changes?

items.title: PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: './.gnupg'
items.body:
I'm trying watchdog for the first time. I've copy pasted the code snippet from README.md. When I try to execute this on my home drive (~), I get a Permission Denied error. 

> PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: './.gnupg'

I'm on macOS High Sierra 10.13.3

Has anyone noticed this before? Below are further details

items.title: Question: how to avoid multithreading
conftest.py missing from PyPI tarball
items.body: Running the tests from a PyPI tarball fails with "E       fixture 'p' not found", because conftest.py is missing from it. It would be nice to add it to the PyPI tarball.

items.title: Add CI for macOS and Windows
items.body:
They are currently not covered and this is *very* bad :)
macOS can be done with Travis-CI. But for Windows, perhaps should we check AppVeyor?

items.title: Drop support for old Python versions
items.body: For instance, we could remove 2.6, 3.2 and 3.3 from the CI. WDYT?

items.title: Changelog is outdated
items.body: The latest version on PyPI is 0.9.0, but [changelog.rst](https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/blob/master/changelog.rst) is only up to 0.8.2.

```bash
odoo.web      |   File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/watchdog/observers/inotify_buffer.py", line 35, in __init__

```

It is related with https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/issues/75

Why?

items.title: Use of yaml.load in watchmedo.py
items.body:
I noticed that watchmedo uses the `yaml.load` method, PyYAML can execute arbitrary commands via the shebang syntax and is recommended by many projects to be swapped for `yaml.safe_load` e.g. OpenStack. https://security.openstack.org/guidelines/dg_avoid-dangerous-input-parsing-libraries.html

https://github.com/gorakhargosh/watchdog/blob/master/src/watchdog/watchmedo.py#L88

Happy to raise a PR against this change if necessary.

items.title: adding multiple handler only one single is used.
items.body:
`
```
class MYRegexMatchingEventHandler(RegexMatchingEventHandler):
    """"""
    def __init__(self, regexes=['.*'], ignore_regexes=[], ignore_directories=False, case_sensitive=False) :
        super().__init__(regexes, ignore_regexes, ignore_directories, case_sensitive)
        
    def on_any_event(self, event):
#         print("{} {} {} {}".format(self.regexes, event.event_type, event.src_path, hasattr(event, "dest_path")))
        print("{} {} {}".format("regex", self, event))

class MYPatternMatchingEventHandler(PatternMatchingEventHandler):
    """"""
    def __init__(self, patterns=None, ignore_patterns=None, ignore_directories=False, case_sensitive=False) :
        super().__init__(patterns, ignore_patterns, ignore_directories, case_sensitive)

    def on_any_event(self, event):
        print("{} {} {}".format("pattern", self, event))


watchpaths = [r"C:\data\exist", r"c:\data\notexist"]

# event_handler = MYRegexMatchingEventHandler([r".*myfolder\d{1,3}."])
event_handler1 =  MYPatternMatchingEventHandler(["*.txt"])
event_handler  =LoggingEventHandler()
observer = MYPollingObserver()

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s - %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
for path in watchpaths:
    if not (os.path.isdir(path) and os.path.exists(path)):
        print("watchpath {} not exist".format(path))
        continue
    print("scheduling watch path {}".format(path))
    watch1 = observer.schedule(event_handler, path, recursive= True)
    observer.add_handler_for_watch(event_handler1, watch1)
#     observer.add_handler_for_watch(event_handler2, watch1)
#     print(watch1)
observer.start()

try:
    while True:
        time.sleep(1)
except InterruptedError:
    observer.stop()
except KeyboardInterrupt:
    observer.stop()    
observer.join()
```
`

Any help would be appreciated. Thanks,

-Eric

I have updated raspbian with:

items.title: Mac issue installing watchdog caused by compilation error in Apple sources
items.body:
```
/usr/include/hfs/hfs_format.h:794:2: error: unknown type name 'uuid_string_t'; did you mean 'io_string_t'?
        uuid_string_t   ext_jnl_uuid;
        ^
```
This would happen whether I was using a pip2 or pip3 to install watchdog. It would also happen if I downloaded the source tarball and followed the instructions on the watchdog site.

The fix:

```
sudo mv /usr/local/include/uuid/uuid.h /usr/local/include/uuid/uuid.h.bak
```

^ A user can always rename it back again after they've successfully installed watchdog.

Maybe the watchdog installer could trap for this error, and suggest something helpful to the user.
